content: this is dmg and we're going to be making tables
okay so we're making tables and we grab our usual ingredients the popsicle
sticks and also the matchsticks and just grab a quite a few depending on how many
you want to have made get a pencil ready and so now I'll just grab two popsicle
sticks just to see the width here I'm looking for about two and a half
centimeters about one inch in width so three of these gets me around about that
figure it doesn't have to be exact so but just try and get it as close to that
as possible and then apply the hot glue down the one edge and stick two together
and then I'll stick the third one together as well using the hot glue so
this is going to form the top of the table and we're going to measure out
what we need in terms of size so my matchsticks are five centimeters so I am
going to measure 2 5 centimeter areas so just starting just after the curve area
I measure 5 centimeters to the middle in five centimeters to the other end then
just rule so we can cut off those curves and then measure to the middle five
centimeters and rule another line so now I've got two five centimeter bits and
we're going to cut off the curves first and then we'll cut through the middle be
sure to use a quite hot hot glue so let it stand and let it run so that you get
a good bond of the hot glue because when you apply this and the glue hasn't had a
chance to be liquefied a lot and has dried too quickly when you cut it it can
come apart so then what I'm doing is I'm just attaching the matchsticks to each
of the long edges matchsticks is a set of five centimeters long which is two
inches and so that if you have longer ones you
just need to cut them down to size so they're to down the long edges so now
I'm just using another match ticket I'm measuring the inside between the two
other matchsticks on both sides and then we will cut those out so that they will
fit in the gap on the short edges then we just grab the hot glue and apply
those to the gap and so now we've got a sort of upside-down tray well not really
if it was a trade wouldn't be upside down but you get what I'm saying okay so
now the reason why I do this is to increase the surface area so that when I
put the legs on these more surfaces for the hot glue to bond to
so it's both aesthetic and practical in terms of what I'm doing so the legs are
now going on so just going to measure the legs as two centimetres and just so
that you figure with on a base is going to be the right sort of height so two
centimetres for that and then we'll just cut off the excess bits on those
matchsticks because as I said they're five centimetres long and then chop the
two in half so they've got four two centimeter legs then I apply hot glue in
the corner and stick the leg in and just hold it in there to dry somewhat and
then you just let it dry and then apply hot glue in each of the other corners
and apply the legs now you will need to do by sight you know we'll need to
adjust the legs because there will be a little bit crooked so just line them up
with your eyes and make sure that they are straight you don't want skew legs
you'll also find there's a lot of wisps that happen as well you can see some
hanging off the bottom there and it's game you know expect that to
happen when you're using very hot glue and relatively easy to to clear off just
grab them and pull them off but wait till the the actual glue has dried
before doing that so that you don't yank off the under-eye pieces so this table
is a little bit unstable because one legs is a little bit too long so I line
it up with the pair of scissors and a lop off the excess bits so that the
table is now stable okay so there we have it and just clear off the excess
wisps as I said before and then we're going to undercoat it with the black
spray paint as you see in video two and I got an assistant to assist me with
that all right so now what I'm going to do is slightly different to how we did
the doors and how we did the bookcase I'm going to just apply Brown straight
on I'm going to use boots of speed just to apply this Brown and apply it thick
so that it gets all over and it's okay if a little bit of black is showing
through that's not a problem give it some depth but we do want to just apply
it thick so that it will dry a dark deep brown so that's what it looks like when
it's dried I've been doing two tables here that's why there's two in the shop
you can produce many at the same time depends on how many you want I don't
really need to do more than two I find two is a good enough number for the
amount of encounters and size of rooms that I have now what I'm doing is I am
applying yellow just straight yellow no mixing with white as I would have done
in previous videos so this is just another way to do wood and I'm dry
brushing the yellow on so I'll wipe off the paint on the on the paper towel and
then apply it onto the wood to lava grain to show through and just keep it
flying in and I love it with my finger every now and again and this is what
they look like on a tile once they've dried nice and easy so that's how easy
it is to make tables if you liked this video click the like
if you want to see future videos you can click the subscribe button and if you
want to see things that I've been working on you can check out my Facebook
page and there's also the website the dmg dot info and if you're interested in
winning a prize you can check out my subscriber competition video see ya
